themes.label: Limestone
themes.rationale: The text refers to 'white stone' (leukolithos), which in the context of Chersonesos typically refers to the local white limestone used for public monuments.
themes.ambiguity_note: While 'white stone' usually implies limestone in this region, it could theoretically refer to marble, though less likely for local decrees.

rationale: This is an honorific decree from Chersonesos Taurica, dating to the Roman period (late 1st or early 2nd century AD). It honors Thrasymedes, a citizen of the mother-city Heraclea Pontica, for his distinguished character and goodwill. The decree grants him proxeny, citizenship, and the right of entry and exit (eisplous and ekplous). It also includes a dating formula that names local officials and refers to the goddess Parthenos as the symbolic 'Queen' (Basilissa) of the city, a unique feature of Chersonesian civic identity. The text specifies that the decree be inscribed on a white stone stele and placed in the most conspicuous part of the acropolis.
